prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA – for wanting to use ‘lads’ and ‘guys’ to a mixed group
  

I play an online team game which is 99% male players. Recently we asked a girl to join our team, lets call her Jane. After match we often say stuff like ‘well done boiz’ and she told us that makes her feel like not part of the team and suggested we say something like ‘well done team’ instead. We all agreed to try, she is part of the team and as good as any of us guys. Jane has said it is difficult for a girl to play in an all male group but I don’t see why as we treat her well.

Yesterday one guy posted in group chat that he could not attend a practice and said ‘Have fun lads and Jane’. Jane responded by telling him that was worse than just saying ‘lads’ and made her feel ‘othered’.

The group had a bit of a chat about it and I said I was gonna keep using ‘lads’ and ‘guys’ because I mean the whole team when I say that and I am not giving in to radical feminism. 

The guy who started this though, said he was sorry for what he wrote and he was trying to include her and he would try to refer to team or people in future.

I ought to be able to use normal words without overly sensitive people feeling hurt by it. I am surprised that some of the other guys are taking her side though.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The person is asking whether they're in the wrong for using terms like "lads" and "guys" in a mixed group where a female teammate, Jane, feels excluded. 

So, first, the team is mostly male, and they added Jane. She asked them to stop using "boiz" because it made her feel left out. They agreed to try "team" instead. Then, another guy used "lads and Jane," which she found even worse because it highlighted her difference. The author defended using "lads" and "guys," saying they mean the whole team and not giving in to radical feminism. Others apologized and changed their language, but the author is upset that others are taking Jane's side.

Hmm. The key points here are about inclusivity and respect. Jane made it clear that these terms make her feel excluded. The author might not see the issue, thinking they're using the words to refer to the whole team. But from Jane's perspective, being singled out by adding her name or using gendered terms can make her feel like she doesn't belong. The author is dismissing her feelings as being overly sensitive and bringing up "radical feminism," which might be invalidating her experience.

In terms of right or wrong, it's about whether respecting someone's feelings is necessary. Even if the intention is inclusive, the impact matters. If Jane feels othered, then the terms are problematic for her. The author's refusal to adjust despite knowing her feelings could be seen as not being considerate. Also, the fact that others apologized and changed their language suggests that there's a valid concern. The author's stance that they shouldn't have to change their language for "overly sensitive" people might be the issue here. So, considering all that, the author is likely in the wrong because they're not taking Jane's valid feelings into account and are being dismissive.
